repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Through a conversion to array. I've tested that and it's ok performance wise,
the C++ compiler can deal with the abstraction (with a small overhead though).

This should fix https://github.com/serge-sans-paille/pythran/issues/1428

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,7 +1556,14 @@ def attributes_known(self):
             self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope('', None, visibility="extern")
             scope.parent_type = self
             scope.directives = {}
-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(
+                    "shape",
+                    CFuncType(CPtrType(c_long_type), [CFuncTypeArg("self", self, None)], nogil=True),
+                    pos=None,
+                    defining=0,
+                cname=" ")

             scope.parent_type = self

-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(

comment_data.body: I wonder if it's worth having a `declare_cgetter()` method for this, instead of calling `declare_cfunction()` directly and then cleaning things up after the fact.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,7 +1556,14 @@ def attributes_known(self):
             self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope('', None, visibility="extern")
             scope.parent_type = self
             scope.directives = {}
-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(
+                    "shape",
+                    CFuncType(CPtrType(c_long_type), [CFuncTypeArg("self", self, None)], nogil=True),
+                    pos=None,
+                    defining=0,
+                cname=" ")
+            shape.is_cgetter = 1

comment_data.body:
Can't this go into the utility code file above? I don't see a need for generating it explicitly.
Also, prefixing it with `__Pyx_` would reduce the chance of naming conflicts.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -759,6 +759,7 @@ def generate_module_preamble(self, env, options, cimported_modules, metadata, co
         env.use_utility_code(UtilityCode.load_cached("FastTypeChecks", "ModuleSetupCode.c"))
         if has_np_pythran(env):
             env.use_utility_code(UtilityCode.load_cached("PythranConversion", "CppSupport.cpp"))
+            code.putln('#define PYTHRAN_SHAPE_ACCESSOR(x) (x.shape().array())')

comment_data.body: mmmh, I really wanted to have something alike a property, what makes you think it's better to have a declare_cfunction?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,7 +1556,14 @@ def attributes_known(self):
             self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope('', None, visibility="extern")
             scope.parent_type = self
             scope.directives = {}
-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(
+                    "shape",
+                    CFuncType(CPtrType(c_long_type), [CFuncTypeArg("self", self, None)], nogil=True),
+                    pos=None,
+                    defining=0,
+                cname=" ")
+            shape.is_cgetter = 1

comment_data.body: That's fine. What I meant was that calling `declare_cfunction()` here in order to get such a property seems like a leaky abstraction. It would be nicer if there was a method `declare_cgetter()` to call in places like this, which could then do the right setup internally, such as calling `declare_cfunction()`, but without requiring the outside code to know about these details.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,7 +1556,14 @@ def attributes_known(self):
             self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope('', None, visibility="extern")
             scope.parent_type = self
             scope.directives = {}
-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(
+                    "shape",
+                    CFuncType(CPtrType(c_long_type), [CFuncTypeArg("self", self, None)], nogil=True),
+                    pos=None,
+                    defining=0,
+                cname=" ")
+            shape.is_cgetter = 1

comment_data.body: Done. what does it mean in the context of cython?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,7 +1556,14 @@ def attributes_known(self):
             self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope('', None, visibility="extern")
             scope.parent_type = self
             scope.directives = {}
-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(

comment_data.body: `extern` means that it's not defined in Cython code but refers to something "external", usually from a header file. The `CClassScope` is declared as `extern` above, which means that all its content should inherit that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,7 +1556,14 @@ def attributes_known(self):
             self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope('', None, visibility="extern")
             scope.parent_type = self
             scope.directives = {}
-            scope.declare_var("shape", CPtrType(c_long_type), None, cname="_shape", is_cdef=True)
+            shape = scope.declare_cfunction(

commit.message:
Support Pythran shape

Through a conversion to array. I've tested that and it's ok performance wise,
the C++ compiler can deal with the abstraction (with a small overhead though).

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Support Pythran shape
